Course Description: The field of Genomics is expanding its horizon with help of high throughput technologies. Scientist are trying to answer fundamental questions related to health, society and human survival outside earth using genomics. With such increase of applications, it constantly needs computational experts for systematic analysis of data and acheiving meaning full insights. Infact the computational experts have now started taking lead in genomic projects. Hence this course is meant to guide students for data analysis approach and steps involved in computational genomics and make them familiar with latest development in genomics.

Course Outcomes.CO1: students can understand source and properties of different kinds of genomic data
Course Outcomes.CO2: students can use tools for regular processing different kinds of genomics data
Course Outcomes.CO3: Students can undertsand the statistical approach used by tools for processing genomics data
Course Outcomes.CO4: Students can perform few complex post processing of data to make meaningful clinical and biological inference

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction to molecular cell biology, central dogma, measurements using microarray and ngs technologies;
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Assignment: (i) Paper reading on cellular functions and biological processes and writing in own words

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction to Genetics/Genomics; Applications to clinical diagnostics;
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Assignment2 : R and Bioconductor; R packages for annotations, short reads handling, microarray analysis and visualizations;

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: NGS concepts and applications; DNA alignment algorithms and assessment; Data QC and Filtering
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Assignment2 : R and Bioconductor; R packages for annotations, short reads handling, microarray analysis and visualizations;

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Applications of NGS in single cell study, bias, drop-out and noise in single cell data
Unsupervised (Clustering and Biclustering) and supervised (Classification), statistical approach in Normalization and Differential gene expression (microarray, bulk RNA-seq and single cell RNA-seq)
Introduction to epigenome and analysis of epigenome ngs data, handling bias and noise, application of epigenome
Weekly Lecture Plan.Assignments: Assignment3: Processing ChIP-seq and RNA-seq datasets to make clinical inference

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Denovo assembly; Assembly assessment; Assembly refinement; Variant calling (SNPs, MNPs, small InDels)
Variant annotations and interpretation, statistical method for effect prediction and QTL; Visualization of genomic data, population Genomics
